newsitem.title: CHINA: China airport expansion plans to peak by 2000.
newsitem.headline: China airport expansion plans to peak by 2000.

text.p: China's ambitious airport expansion programme will peak during the current five-year plan with six new projects getting under way and 14 completed or continuing, the China Daily said on Monday.
The key project for the 1996-2000 period is the expansion of Beijing's airport to be completed in October 1999 at a cost of 9.2 billion yuan ($1.1 billion), the newspaper said.

The six new projects are Shanghai's Pudong airport, Zhongchuan airport in western Lanzhou city, Wujiabei airport in southwestern Kunming city, an expansion of the Shuangliu airport in southwestern Chengdu city, the Beijing air control centre and the Tianjin-Beijing fuel supply project.
It gave no figure for the total cost of the projects and did not specify how each project would be financed.

But it quoted Bao Peide, deputy director of the Civil Aviation Administration of China, as saying that stock issuance and direct foreign investment were increasingly being used to fund airport projects.
Foreign investors would not be allowed to hold more than 49 percent of a domestic airport, he said.

Among the other projects under way or nearing completion were a runway expansion at Urumqi in the northwestern region of Xinjiang, the airport expansion at Harbin in northeastern China and construction of a terminal building for the Gaoqi airport in the southeastern city of Xiamen.
